Definition: In this task, you will be given four sentences of a story. Your job is to select an incorrect end sentence from (A) and (B) such that the story sounds incomplete and incoherent.

Positive Examples.input:
Sentence1: Rick grew up in a troubled household. Sentence2: He never found good support in family, and turned to gangs. Sentence3: It wasn't long before Rick got shot in a robbery. Sentence4: The incident caused him to turn a new leaf. 
 (A) He is happy now. (B) He joined a gang.
Positive Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, the incident turned a new leaf to Rick's life; so, he must be happy now. Also, he was previously in gang, so, this incident cannot make him to join a gang. So, B is incorrect.

Positive Examples.input:
Sentence1: Laverne needs to prepare something for her friend's party. Sentence2: She decides to bake a batch of brownies. Sentence3: She chooses a recipe and follows it closely. Sentence4: Laverne tests one of the brownies to make sure it is delicious. 
 (A) The brownies are so delicious Laverne eats two of them. (B) Laverne doesn't go to her friend's party.
Positive Examples.explanation: As mentioned in the third sentence, Laverne follows the recipe closely; brownies should be delicious and she should not cancel going to her friend's party. So, B is incorrect.

Positive Examples.input:
Sentence1: Sarah had been dreaming of visiting Europe for years. Sentence2: She had finally saved enough for the trip. Sentence3: She landed in Spain and traveled east across the continent. Sentence4: She didn't like how different everything was. 
 (A) Sarah then decided to move to Europe. (B) Sarah decided that she preferred her home over Europe.
Positive Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, Sarah didn't like that everything was different in Europe; she must have preferred her home over Europe. So, A is incorrect.

Negative Examples.input:
Sentence1: Rick grew up in a troubled household. Sentence2: He never found good support in family, and turned to gangs. Sentence3: It wasn't long before Rick got shot in a robbery. Sentence4: The incident caused him to turn a new leaf. 
 (A) He is happy now. (B) He joined a gang.
Negative Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, the incident turned a new leaf to Rick's life; so, he must be happy now. However, A is correct answer, not incorrect.

Negative Examples.input:
Sentence1: Laverne needs to prepare something for her friend's party. Sentence2: She decides to bake a batch of brownies. Sentence3: She chooses a recipe and follows it closely. Sentence4: Laverne tests one of the brownies to make sure it is delicious. 
 (A) The brownies are so delicious Laverne eats two of them. (B) Laverne doesn't go to her friend's party.
Negative Examples.explanation: As mentioned in the third sentence, Laverne follows the recipe closely; brownies should be delicious. However, A is correct answer, not incorrect.

Negative Examples.input:
Sentence1: Sarah had been dreaming of visiting Europe for years. Sentence2: She had finally saved enough for the trip. Sentence3: She landed in Spain and traveled east across the continent. Sentence4: She didn't like how different everything was. 
 (A) Sarah then decided to move to Europe. (B) Sarah decided that she preferred her home over Europe.
Negative Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, Sarah didn't like that everything was different in Europe; she must have preferred her home over Europe. However, B is correct answer, not incorrect.

Instances.input:
Sentence1: Anna wanted chicken wings. Sentence2: She drove her car all the way to Buffalo. Sentence3: There, she found an authentic wing restaurant. Sentence4: She ordered herself a dozen hot wings. 
 (A) Anna ate all the wings as she drove home. (B) Anna was happy with her meal of lasagna.

Sentence1: The first day of school I walked there with two of my closest friends. Sentence2: We were all very nervous. Sentence3: When we got to school we checked the class list for third grade. Sentence4: All three of us were assigned to the same classroom! 
 (A) We couldn't believe our luck. (B) All three of us were very disappointed.

Sentence1: Max was a very bright boy. Sentence2: But he would become lost in his own vivid imagination. Sentence3: No matter how hard he tried, he found himself daydreaming. Sentence4: Max did not do very well in school. 
 (A) Max consistently failed. (B) Max's teacher's praised his creativity.

Sentence1: I went to babysit my 5-year-old nephew in San Francisco. Sentence2: My sister encouraged me to bike her kid to school. Sentence3: I was afraid to bike across the city with my nephew in tow. Sentence4: Instead, we biked through Golden Gate Park to the beach and the zoo. 
 (A) I do not have a sister. (B) We had a great time!

Sentence1: Gina's sister cut her ankle on broken glass. Sentence2: The blood ran down her foot and into her shoe. Sentence3: When she saw the blood she ran home. Sentence4: Gina ran behind her, but couldn't keep up. 
 (A) When they got home they all had ice cream. (B) Gina's sister went to the doctor.

Sentence1: Last night was very scary. Sentence2: We had a tornado warning and terrible thunderstorms. Sentence3: Unfortunately my concert for violin was not canceled. Sentence4: I was required to show up but during the performance lights went out. 
 (A) Nobody seemed to notice what had happened. (B) We could not see our sheet music.

Sentence1: My friend  Cam was an Amazon bookseller. Sentence2: He had 4,000 books stored in a garage. Sentence3: He made enough money to live simply. Sentence4: His house caught on fire one day and he lost his collection. 
 (A) Cam has since decided to insure his belongings. (B) Afterwards, Cam was able to sell more books than he ever had.

Sentence1: I decided to rent a movie when friends came over last night. Sentence2: After looking through selections we decided on horror. Sentence3: We picked a great movie and sat down with popcorn. Sentence4: It was really scarey! 
 (A) I had a hard time falling asleep that night. (B) Overall I was dissatisfied with the night.
